title: Can there be consensus on Brexit?
text: An experimental Pol.Is question. The intractable and fuzzy nature of Brexit means many people ostensibly on the same side end up fighting it out. Is there any consensus to be had? Since Pol.Is can apparently find that out, it seems like a good tool to use.

comments.text: Pressure against Brexit should be directed at the Conservative Party, who have the (slight) majority in the Commons, not Labour.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Labour may not be able to make substantive promises to Remainers, but it's harmful that they have no message for Remainers at all.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: EU may be unreformable, but principles of solidarity btw nations, FoM, common workers rights are so important we should try to salvage it
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A binary out/in vote where an ill-defined wishlist of lies & fantasies ran against a real flawed product of compromise was an awful idea
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tories don't care whether Brexit will be harmful as they believe there will be plenty of others to blame (eg. EU, Immigrants, Remainers)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A second referendum would be pointless as it would be run on the same lines as the first and majority of people will be no better informed.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The referendum result produced no clear objectives for the Brexit negotiations. No options should be ruled out at this stage.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Labour's manifesto position allows them the freedom to reject any Brexit deal which could harm jobs in the UK
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Lexit is utopian, but so is the case for workers' unity within the EU; the EU is still a capitalist club.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Labour can (still) stop Brexit - but through delaying tactics, not outright opposition.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Brexit was two projects in one - "UK FTZ plc" and "let's make racism the core issue in British politics".
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 'Lexit' is just the stupidest fucking thing imaginable
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There's no point "opposing Brexit" at this stage. It's a rock rolling down a hill, the inertia is too great for it to be stopped.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Opposition to Brexit as a whole won't stop it, but opposition to the component parts of it just might.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The varied nature of EU institutions means everyone likes some parts of it and hates other parts (whether they know it or not).
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: "The EU" as a concept is too big and too varied to be summed up simply, which is why an "in/out" vote was a stupid idea in the first place.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The current Brexit negotiating team are woefully inadequate for the task in every aspect. Replacing them should be a priority.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Because of the way the referendum demographics broke down, both parties are in real danger that a political misstep could ruin them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The EU is institutionally against workers rights
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There is nothing left wing about the EU
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should not be a second referendum on the original question
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should be a referendum on the final deal between the UK and the EU
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The UK's borders are basically unprotected, thanks to the EU.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Brexit will be a success as long as we all stay firm against the EU and don't let the government negotiate our sovereign rights and freedoms away.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The EU referendum has split the electorate in ways that traditional party lines cannot capture, and we haven't yet worked out how to react as a nation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A Pro-EU centrist party could have done better, but the Lib Dems were poisoned by their association with Tory Austerity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Conservatives are the only party dedicated to making a success of Brexit.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Whatever happens, the UK is better off out of the Euro.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am opposed to the neoliberal economics the EU stands for, but voted to remain as I did not trust the Tories to administer Brexit.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Other issues are more important to me than Brexit
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Brexit vote wasn't really about the EU, but was rather a proxy vote on various issues. Unfortunately they weren't all the same issues.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A referendum should not be binding for a decision of this magnitude.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A free trade deal with the USA will be more restrictive and onerous than any EU arrangement, especially if negotiated under a Trump presidency.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The idea of sovereignty is badly defined. What does it matter if we gain the theoretical freedom from European institutions if we end up practically constrained by those institutions in any event?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I can speak a European language.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Northern Ireland/Republic of Ireland border is a huge issue that isn't being given enough attention.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Single Market is important for the prosperity of the country.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Freedom of Movement is an issue that personally affects me or someone close to me - it could lead to me having to leave the country, or to future difficulties in seeing my family.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I consider myself middle class.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I consider myself working class.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Labour should listen to the genuine concerns of leave voters and not just try to override a referendum because they don't like the results.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Labour should oppose the Brexit process.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Labour was right to support the article 50 vote.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There is some difference between Labour and the Tories on Brexit, but on the fundamentals they're still so similar as to make no practical difference.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There's literally no difference between Labour and the Tories on Brexit.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Brexit could be a success, but not let by this incompetent Tory party.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I've changed my mind about my vote since the referendum.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think we should support the referendum result.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I voted to Remain.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I voted to Leave.
comments.author: Anonymous
